How We Hear

Understanding the remarkable process of hearing and how sound travels through your ear.

The Hearing Process

Hearing is a complex process that involves multiple parts of the ear working together to convert sound waves into electrical signals that your brain can interpret.

The Outer Ear

The outer ear consists of the pinna (the visible part of the ear) and the ear canal. Sound waves enter through the pinna and travel down the ear canal to the eardrum.

The shape of the pinna helps to collect sound waves and funnel them into the ear canal, while also helping us determine the direction of sounds.

The Middle Ear

When sound waves reach the eardrum, they cause it to vibrate. These vibrations are transmitted through three tiny bones called ossicles: the malleus (hammer), incus (anvil), and stapes (stirrup).

The ossicles amplify the sound vibrations and transmit them to the inner ear through the oval window, a membrane-covered opening.

The Inner Ear

The inner ear contains the cochlea, a snail-shaped structure filled with fluid and lined with thousands of tiny hair cells. When vibrations enter the cochlea, they create waves in the fluid.

These waves cause the hair cells to bend, converting the mechanical energy into electrical signals. Different hair cells respond to different frequencies, allowing us to distinguish between various sounds.

The Brain

The electrical signals generated by the hair cells travel along the auditory nerve to the brain. The brain's auditory cortex processes these signals, allowing us to recognize and understand sounds.

This entire process happens almost instantaneously, allowing us to hear and respond to sounds in real-time.
